critique: The document reflects President Roosevelt's approval of a Code of Fair Competition for the Optical Manufacturing Industry under the National Industrial Recovery Act of 1933. This act was a key component of the New Deal, representing a significant expansion of the federal government's role in the economy. The code aims to regulate competition within the industry, indicating a move away from laissez-faire economics. The creation of an industry committee with government appointees further illustrates federal oversight and intervention. There is no discussion of immigration, executive power, federalism, security/liberty, or social inclusion.
